content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze this game strategically to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds.

Let's first consider the payoff differences between choosing R and B:
- Choosing R when the opponent chooses B results in a loss of 35$ (you get 0$ while they get 35$).
- Choosing B when the opponent chooses R results in a gain of 35$.
- In all other cases, both choices result in the same payoff.

Since I don't know my opponent's strategy, I will assume they are rational and will try to maximize their earnings as well. Given that the game has 75 rounds, there are two possibilities:
1) My opponent and I choose the same strategy most of the time (either R or B). In this case, choosing the opposite strategy would result in losing a lot more money than gaining by choosing the same strategy. Therefore, it makes sense to pick the same strategy as my opponent for optimal results.
2) My opponent and I have no consistent pattern, and we switch strategies frequently. In this case, it doesn't matter if we pick R or B since there is a 50-50 chance of losing or gaining 35$ in each round by choosing the opposite strategy. However, since the game lasts for 75 rounds, I would still lean towards picking the same strategy as my opponent to minimize losses due to switching strategies too often.

Given these considerations, it seems that picking the same strategy as my opponent (R or B) might be the optimal choice to maximize earnings over the long run. Therefore, my choice would be {R} (or {B}, depending on what I assume my opponent will pick first). However, since I don't have any information about my opponent's initial choice, I can't make a definitive decision without observing their move in the first round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

With my opponent choosing R in the previous round, I now have information about their strategy. Since they chose R while I chose B, it suggests that my opponent is more likely to choose R than B (as R results in a higher payoff for them).

In the current situation, if I were to stick with my initial choice of B, I would lose 35$ in the next round since my opponent will likely choose R again. To minimize losses and maximize earnings, it makes more sense for me to switch my strategy to R in this specific situation.

So, in the next round, I would choose {R}.
